title: Quantum Frequency Converter: Telecom to Visible (Corrected)
description: Converts single photons from telecom wavelength (1550nm) to visible wavelength (600.4nm) via sum-frequency generation while preserving quantum properties

parameters.description: Heralded single photons at telecom wavelength
Periodically-poled lithium niobate for 1550nm+980nm→600.4nm conversion (energy conservation: 1/1550 + 1/980 = 1/600.4)
Reflects converted visible light (600.4nm) upward, transmits pump and unconverted signal
Absorbs residual pump and unconverted telecom light
Narrow bandpass centered at 600nm to eliminate residual pump and unconverted signal
Silicon avalanche photodiode for visible photon detection at 600nm

physics_explanation: Single telecom photons at 1550nm are combined with a strong 980nm pump laser in a PPLN crystal where sum-frequency generation occurs. Energy conservation dictates that the output wavelength must be 600.4nm (1/λ_out = 1/1550 + 1/980). The nonlinear interaction preserves quantum coherence and photon statistics while upconverting to a wavelength where silicon detectors have high efficiency. Quasi-phase-matching in PPLN with appropriate poling period (~19.2μm) and temperature control ensures efficient conversion.

component_justifications.Telecom Photon Source: Generates heralded single photons at 1550nm, the standard telecom wavelength for quantum communication applications
component_justifications.Fiber Input Coupler: Couples single photons from fiber into free-space optics with high efficiency (85%) while maintaining single-mode operation
component_justifications.Telecom Collimator: Collimates the telecom beam to 2mm diameter for optimal mode-matching in the nonlinear crystal
component_justifications.Signal Focusing Lens: Focuses the 1550nm signal beam into the PPLN crystal to maximize nonlinear interaction strength
component_justifications.Pump Laser: Provides strong 980nm classical pump field (500mW) required for efficient sum-frequency generation without adding excessive noise
component_justifications.Pump Focusing Lens: Focuses pump beam to match the signal beam waist in the crystal for optimal spatial mode overlap
component_justifications.Dichroic Combiner: Combines the 1550nm signal and 980nm pump beams collinearly by reflecting 980nm and transmitting 1550nm
component_justifications.PPLN Crystal: Periodically-poled lithium niobate crystal with 19.2μm poling period provides quasi-phase-matched SFG for 1550nm+980nm→600.4nm conversion (corrected to satisfy energy conservation)
component_justifications.Output Collimation Lens: Recollimates the output beams after the crystal for efficient separation and filtering
component_justifications.Dichroic Separator: Separates the converted 600.4nm photons from residual pump and unconverted signal by reflecting visible light upward
component_justifications.Pump Beam Dump: Safely absorbs the high-power residual pump and any unconverted telecom photons to prevent detector saturation
component_justifications.Bandpass Filter: Narrow 10nm bandpass filter centered at 600nm with OD6 rejection eliminates any remaining pump or signal photons
component_justifications.Coupling Lens: Focuses the converted 600.4nm photons into single-mode fiber for delivery to detector
component_justifications.Visible Fiber Coupler: Couples visible photons into single-mode fiber with 75% efficiency while providing spatial filtering
component_justifications.Silicon APD: Silicon avalanche photodiode provides 75% detection efficiency at 600nm with low dark counts and 350ps timing resolution for single-photon detection

expected_outcome: Single telecom photons are efficiently converted to 600.4nm orange-light photons with conversion efficiency of 30-60% while preserving quantum statistics (sub-Poissonian photon number distribution, g^(2)(0) < 1). The APD will detect single photons with high signal-to-noise ratio, enabling quantum communication protocols with visible-wavelength detectors. Coincidence measurements between heralding detector and APD will confirm preservation of quantum correlations through the frequency conversion process.
